BUSINESS.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - BUSINESS section of AMD's report:

• The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 defines forward-looking statements as those that include words such as "believes," "expects," "may," "will," "should," "seeks," "intends," "plans," "pro forma," "estimates," and their negatives, or variations.

• AMD expects international sales to continue being a significant portion of total sales in the foreseeable future.

• The company's cash, cash equivalents, and short-term investment balances, along with its availability under certain credit facilities and commercial paper program, are expected to be sufficient to fund operations over the next 12 months and beyond.

• AMD expects that actions associated with the 2024 Restructuring Plan will be substantially completed by the end of the first quarter of fiscal year 2025.

• The company anticipates recognizing revenue from remaining performance obligations in the next 12 months.

• A small number of customers are expected to continue accounting for a substantial part of AMD's revenue and receivables in the future.

ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART I - ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS section in bullet points:

• Intel Corporation's dominance of the microprocessor market and its aggressive business practices may limit AMD's ability to compete effectively on a level playing field (34% market share).
• Nvidia's dominance in the graphics processing unit market and its aggressive business practices may limit AMD's ability to compete effectively on a level playing field (33% market share).
• The semiconductor industry is highly cyclical and has experienced severe downturns, with some periods experiencing declines of over 20%.
• Economic and market uncertainty may adversely impact AMD's business and operating results.
• Unfavorable currency exchange rate fluctuations could adversely affect AMD's business.
• If AMD loses Microsoft Corporation's support for its products or other software vendors do not design and develop software to run on AMD's products, its ability to sell its products could be materially adversely affected.
• Costs related to defective products could have a material adverse effect on AMD.
• AMD relies on third-party companies for the design, manufacture and supply of motherboards, software, memory and other computer platform components to support its business and products.

ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY section in bullet points:

• AMD's cybersecurity risk management program is designed to protect confidentiality, integrity, and availability of critical systems and information.
• The program is based on the National Institute of Standards and Technology Cybersecurity Framework (NIST CSF), AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF), and other industry practices and standards.
• AMD conducts periodic risk assessments to identify cybersecurity risks to its critical systems, information, services, and enterprise IT environment.
• The company has a security team responsible for managing cybersecurity risk assessment processes, security controls, and detection and response to cybersecurity incidents.
• AMD uses external service providers to assess, evaluate, test, or assist with aspects of its security controls and processes.
• The company conducts active testing, including penetration tests, attack simulations, and tabletop exercises.
• Cybersecurity awareness training is provided to employees, incident response personnel, and senior management.
• AMD has a cybersecurity incident response plan that includes procedures for responding to cybersecurity incidents.
• A third-party cyber risk management process is in place for vendors, including a security assessment and contracting program based on their risk profile.

ITEM 2. PROPERTIES.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 2. PROPERTIES section in bullet points:

• As of December 28, 2024, AMD has approximately 6 million square feet of space for research and development, engineering, administrative, and warehouse use worldwide.
• Approximately 5 million square feet of leased space and 1 million square feet of owned space are utilized by the company.
• The headquarters is located in Santa Clara, California.
• Significant operations are also present in Austin, Texas; San Jose, California; Shanghai, China; Markham, Ontario, Canada; Longmont, Colorado; Dublin, Ireland; Singapore; Bengaluru and Hyderabad, India.

ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT’S COMMON E.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT’S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES:

• Our common stock is listed on The NASDAQ Global Select Market (NASDAQ) under the symbol “AMD”.
• As of January 24, 2025, there were 5,028 registered holders of our common stock.
• The closing price of our common stock was $122.84 per share as reported on NASDAQ on January 24, 2025.
• We have an approved stock repurchase program authorizing up to $12 billion of our common stock (Repurchase Program).
• We expect to fund repurchases through cash generated from operations.
• During fiscal year 2024, we withheld approximately 4.6 million shares at an average price of $154.53 per share as payment of withholding taxes in connection with the vesting and exercise of equity awards.

ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANAL.summary:
Here are the key facts from the MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS section:

• Net revenue increased by 14% to $25.8 billion in 2024, compared to $22.7 billion in 2023.
• Data Center net revenue increased by 94% to $12.6 billion in 2024, driven by higher sales of AMD Instinct GPUs and EPYC CPUs.
• Client segment net revenue increased by 52% to $7.1 billion in 2024, primarily due to higher sales of Ryzen mobile and desktop processors.
• Gaming net revenue decreased by 58% to $2.6 billion in 2024, compared to $6.2 billion in 2023.
• Embedded net revenue decreased by 33% to $3.6 billion in 2024, compared to $5.3 billion in 2023.
• AMD launched its 5th Gen EPYC processors with the "Zen 5" core architecture designed to deliver leadership performance and efficiency.
• The company unveiled an accelerated AMD Instinct accelerator roadmap to deliver an annual cadence of leadership AI solutions.
• AMD Ryzen AI 300 Series processors were launched, combining leadership compute capabilities with an industry-leading NPU powered by XDNA 2 architecture for next-generation AI PCs.

ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DI.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURE ABOUT MARKET RISK in bullet points:

• As of December 28, 2024, our investment portfolio consisted of fixed income instruments, time deposits, and commercial paper.
• A hypothetical 50 basis-point (half percentage point) increase or decrease in interest rates compared to rates on December 28, 2024 would have affected the fair value of our cash equivalent and investment portfolio by approximately $6 million.
• As of December 28, 2024, all of our outstanding long-term debt had fixed interest rates, resulting in minimal exposure to market risk for changes in interest rates.
• Our investments in debt securities were A-rated by at least one of the rating agencies as of December 28, 2024.
• We maintain a foreign currency hedging strategy using derivative financial instruments to mitigate risks associated with changes in foreign currency exchange rates.
• All of our foreign currency forward contracts matured within 24 months as of December 30, 2023 and December 28, 2024.

ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEM.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA in bullet points:

• AMD's fiscal year is either 52 or 53 weeks, ending on the last Saturday in December.
• Fiscal years 2024 and 2023 consisted of 52 weeks each, while fiscal year 2022 consisted of 53 weeks.
• Unbilled receivables of $1.1 billion as of December 30, 2023 were reclassified from within Accounts receivable, net to within Prepaid expenses and other current assets on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
• AMD uses a 52- or 53-week fiscal year ending on the last Saturday in December.
• The Company's standard contractual terms for customers are typically net days.
• Shipping and handling costs associated with product sales are included in cost of sales.

ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES in bullet points:

• As of December 28, 2024, AMD carried out an evaluation under the supervision and participation of management (including CEO and CFO) to assess the effectiveness of its disclosure controls.
• The evaluation is performed quarterly to report conclusions on the effectiveness of disclosure controls in periodic reports (Form 10-Q and Form 10-K).
• The overall goal of these evaluations is to monitor and modify disclosure controls as necessary.
• AMD intends to maintain disclosure controls as dynamic systems that are adjusted based on changing circumstances.
• As of December 28, 2024, the CEO and CFO concluded that AMD's disclosure controls were effective at the reasonable assurance level.

ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS A.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE in bullet points:

• AMD has adopted an insider trading policy governing the purchase, sale, and other dispositions of its securities by directors, officers, employees, and other individuals associated with it.
• A copy of AMD's insider trading policy is filed as Exhibit 19.1 to this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
• The information about corporate governance procedures, including director elections and executive officer appointments, is incorporated from the 2025 Proxy Statement.
• There were no material changes to the procedures by which stockholders may recommend nominees to AMD's board of directors.
